ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about various structures of government and the basis of philosophy. I also enjoyed the opportunity to read new literary works and hear other students' opinions on them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths- a variety of works, small class, opportunity to present and receive feedback
weakness- no particular structure, stated that no background in philosophy was necessary but I found that it was actually VERY necessary, assignments were vague

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend the class to upperclassmen with a background in philosophy and an interest in Marxism. I would say that the class is an easy A, but my grade on canvas still says N/A despite turning in multiple assignments, including a midterm essay.
Yes - a kind and brilliant professor teaches compelling, urgent matter with care for our learning

Marxism is misunderstood by the majority of people that discuss it (in politics, in the media, in casual conversation) and it is such a fundamental concept in history and modern civilization that it seems irresponsible not to learn about its theoretical foundations.

extras.title:
JDST 677 01/CPLT 574 01/JDST 326 01/LITR 317 01
        Marxism and Literature/Marxist Theory of Literature
